text: This looked like being a run-of-the-mill opening game a week ago but Martin O'Neill's resignation allied to the prospect of James Milner starting for Villa has added a fair bit of spice to the occasion. For Kevin MacDonald, Villa's caretaker, it could be the first chance to stake a claim for the job. He does, however, have a problem in central defence, with Curtis Davies, Carlos Cuéllar and James Collins all injured. Pablo Barrera, Tal Ben Haim and Frédéric Piquionne could all make their debuts for West Ham but Thomas Hitzlsperger is struggling. Stuart James

It is a case of "as you were" for these clubs given their strong finishes to the previous campaign – Everton, unbeaten in 11, were the only side to defeat Blackburn in their last nine – and relative inactivity in the transfer market. Both are likely to resist handing full debuts to strikers unproven at Premier League level: Mame Biram Diouf, loaned from Manchester United, and free transfer Jermaine Beckford. Mikel Arteta was irresistible in April's 3-2 victory at Ewood Park and the Spaniard's retention on a five-year deal was as significant a piece of business as any all summer. Richard Gibson

With Martin Petrov on one wing for Bolton and Lee Chung-yong on the other there should be some genuinely entertaining football played at the Reebok this season – though with Manchester United, Arsenal and Aston Villa to play in September, the visitors could do with picking up early points. The new manager Mark Hughes has made it clear he is prepared to take Fulham in another, more pragmatic, direction to improve on a record of one league win away from home last season. Reports suggest some players are finding it hard to accept. Richard Rae

The fixture list, on paper at least, has been kind to Chelsea given their toils in pre-season. The champions' World Cup contingent are still finding their feet, with four successive friendlies lost, though the suspicion remains that they will hit the ground running against newly promoted opponents. West Bromwich Albion have not even scored a league goal at Stamford Bridge since 1988 and Roberto Di Matteo, once the hearty welcome back to an old haunt dies down, could be in for a troubled top-flight managerial baptism. Certainly, the size of the task ahead could be made very clear on the opening afternoon. Dominic Fifield

Birmingham finished six points ahead of Sunderland last season – despite scoring considerably fewer goals, a problem they have sought to address by recruiting the monolithic Serbia striker Nikola Zigic to support Cameron Jerome. By contrast, today's hosts had their 24-goal forward Darren Bent in their lineup, but they could not find the necessary defensive nous to secure better results. The manager Steve Bruce seems to have gone out of his way to correct that flaw and there are now eight different centre-backs at the club. Richard Flower

The fixture computer has pulled out the stops here, with an immediate re-run of last season's fight for fourth. Harry Redknapp's victory at Eastlands was one of the finest of his career but City want to bump Spurs out of the top four this time, en route to world domination, and the desire for revenge will pep the game. The sub-plots are numerous. Spurs have one eye on Tuesday's Champions League qualifier against Young Boys while Roberto Mancini must decide on Joe Hart or Shay Given, not to mention a clutch of potential debutants, and then there is Craig Bellamy. David Hytner

Blackpool's Ian Holloway has endured a frustrating summer. Due to financial constraints, he has missed out on a host of transfer targets. He has managed to recruit three unlikely musketeers from France in Ludovic Sylvestre, Malaury Martin and Elliot Grandin as well as Craig Cathcart, a 21-year-old defender from Manchester United. Holloway is speaking of "climbing mountains", but promises to attack, come what may. Wigan have hardly broken the bank either, but have replaced Titus Bramble with Paraguay's Antolín Alcaraz, and have Ali Al Habsi on loan from Bolton. Gary Caldwell (hip) is their only absentee. The battle for survival starts here. Joe Lovejoy

Wolves finished nine points behind Stoke last season but a 15th-place finish in their first year back among the big boys was highly respectable. For the tilt at defeating second-season syndrome Mick McCarthy has recruited Stephen Hunt, Steven Fletcher and Jelle Van Damme. McCarthy would be delighted to emulate Stoke and improve the club's standing by at least a place, after Tony Pulis guided City to 11th in 2009-10, 12 months on from their debut Premier League year. Pulis has signed Kenwyne Jones for £8m but he needs to improve a poor goals-to-games ratio. Jamie Jackson

Tomorrow will bring a certain ambivalence to Anfield on an afternoon when there ought only to be unmitigated excitement at the start of a new campaign. The ownership issues linger yet supporters who yearn for the club to be bought must also wish the best for the manager Roy Hodgson. However, the visitors could also be uneasy since Arsène Wenger has not yet made the signings to give Arsenal a greater durability and key players such as Cesc Fábregas and Robin van Persie have yet to reach optimum fitness. Kevin McCarra

It is difficult to imagine anything but a home win for the deposed champions but that said, the same fixture on the opening weekend two seasons ago ended in a 1-1 draw and Chris Hughton's side should not be short of self-belief after their promotion as winners of the Championship. Sir Alex Ferguson now has six forwards to choose from after the arrival of Bébé from Vitória de Guimarães and this could be the first time Michael Owen faces his former club. Do not bet your mortgage on him being applauded from the visiting end.

Ian Holloway said in such a humble and endearing way that he had always dreamed of taking a team to Arsenal and, after last Saturday's thumping triumph at Wigan, Blackpool will head south with the feeling that anything could happen. The nation has bought into the Seasiders' fairytale yet this feels as if it might be the day when sobering reality intervenes. Arsenal have injuries, as they always do, but they also have the captain Cesc Fábregas back in the squad, Robin van Persie eager to start and Marouane Chamakh fired up for a home debut. David Hytner

Home form was key for Birmingham City last season – they will hope to kick off in the same vein this afternoon. It will be a strange day for Matt Derbyshire, who joined Birmingham on loan from Olympiakos earlier this week, and begins life with Blues against his former English club. 'I had a fantastic time at Blackburn, it's a nice club, the club I supported as a boy,' said Derbyshire. 'I know most of the players and they know me, but you've got to put it behind you and concentrate on winning the game for Birmingham.' John Ashdown

Three points on the board, a relatively substantial spend this summer, and now Mick McCarthy is indulging in mind games ahead of the visit to Goodison Park. 'They'll be looking forward to us coming,' he claimed yesterday, knowing full well trepidation surrounds Everton ahead of their first home game. Defeat at Blackburn stunned the optimists on the opening day and, with Aston Villa and Manchester United to follow in the league, David Moyes' team could be playing catch-up yet again unless they find a way to break a Wolves team that held them to a draw twice last season. Andy Hunter

Tottenham might have escaped with what Harry Redknapp described as a 'great defeat' in Switzerland in midweek but there has been a high price to pay. Spurs have a major injury crisis ahead of their trip to Stoke, with Redknapp probably unable to fill the substitutes' bench and missing three of his four frontline strikers. Stoke's concerns that Kenwyne Jones suffered a serious injury at Wolves last weekend were allayed and the club-record signing is set to make his home debut this afternoon as Tony Pulis's side seek to pick up their first points of the season. Stuart James

Most teams get beaten at Chelsea, albeit not quite so badly as West Bromwich did last week, but with Liverpool, Tottenham, Manchester United and Arsenal among their next six league opponents, Albion need to pick up points today if they are not to find themselves anchored at the foot of the table for the foreseeable future. It was an almost equally embarrassing opening week for Sunderland, after an NHS survey suggested their supporters were the fattest in England. Steve Bruce has little choice but to put out an attacking side, which means the entertainment levels could be as high as the visiting fans' cholesterol levels. Richard Rae

West Ham can only improve on their abject performance at Villa Park, where a 3-0 defeat let them off lightly. Avram Grant's main concern will be to restore confidence and discipline to a defence that all but surrendered. Scott Parker, as ever, is the crucial figure and his ability to link defence with attack will be the key this season, always assuming that the resolve not to sell him holds good. Bolton have already improved on last season, when they lost their opening three games, and will hope to build on a workmanlike 0-0 draw with Fulham. David Lacey

Having seen your defence taken apart by a half-fit Marlon Harewood and Gary Taylor-Fletcher, the last thing you want is to face a team who have won their last four league games by a collective score of 23-0. That is the scenario facing the Wigan manager, Roberto Martínez, which may be why a truce with the wantaway Charles N'Zogbia, who was dropped for the rout by Blackpool, has been arranged. Carlo Ancelotti has added Ramires, his new signing from Benfica, to his squad but will remember he lost 3-1 on Chelsea's last visit to the DW Stadium. Tim Rich

Mark Hughes may find that Roy Hodgson is a very hard act to follow and never more so than on a day when Manchester United visit. Under him, Fulham defeated these opponents 3-0 and 2-0 on their last two trips to Craven Cottage. United, all the same, have looked fresh and incisive so far in this campaign while beating Chelsea, in the Community Shield, and then Newcastle United in the Premier League, with half-a-dozen goals scored in total and veterans such as Ryan Giggs and Paul Scholes looking in fine form. Kevin McCarra

It is tempting to depict this a clash between the future and the past. Manchester City enjoy all the means and will expect, at the minimum, to qualify for the Champions League this season. Liverpool crave a return to that lucrative tournament and Roy Hodgson's know-how has to bring new impetus to the club. City, despite the outlay, have not been exhilarating so far, but a goalless draw at Spurs and a 1-0 win away to Timisoara in the first leg of the Europa League play-offs suggested that solidity is the immediate priority. Kevin McCarra

New signing Sébastien Squillaci is unlikely to make his debut for Arsenal as he is lacking match fitness after missing Sevilla's Champions League play-off with Braga last week to avoid being cup-tied. Fellow centre-back Laurent Koscielny returns after a ban so there is no need for the manager, Arsène Wenger, to rush Squilacci back into action. Blackburn may have their top-scorer last season, David Dunn, back after the midfielder recovered from a groin injury but Keith Andrews will be missing with a similar problem. Richard Flower

Reality has bitten hard since Blackpool's fairytale start to life in the Premier League – a thumping at the Emirates followed by Carling Cup elimination in Milton Keynes – but home games will determine whether top-flight survival is anything more than a pipe dream. Despite a seamless managerial transition from Roy Hodgson to Mark Hughes, Fulham would be high on the Tangerine wishlist for Bloomfield Road's first date: a full season has gone by since the London club's last away league win, at Portsmouth 12 months ago, and they have scored just once in their past five matches. Richard Gibson

With 12 league goals to their name already this season and 21 in their last three home games, it is safe to say that there are better times to visit Chelsea. That seven of those 21 goals came without reply in Stoke's last visit to Stamford Bridge in April will cause only further distress to Tony Pulis. The Stoke manager could be without the £8m signing Kenwyne Jones, who has been missing since injuring an ankle in the defeat at Wolves. Carlo Ancelotti has no such problems and may give a debut to the Brazilian Ramires. Evan Fanning

West Ham, with two defeats and six goals conceded, could be obliging opponents for Wayne Rooney to end his 18-hour goal drought. Rooney has recovered from the bug that ruled him out against Fulham last Sunday, adding to the potential reasons why the West Ham captain, Scott Parker, admitted to 'dreading' this fixture. It won't get any easier for Avram Grant's team – next up is Chelsea. The defender Mathew Upson is likely to play after the facial injury that ruled him out of the Carling Cup tie on Tuesday. Daniel Taylor

Fresh from their cruise past Young Boys into the Champions League proper, Spurs will be licking their lips at the prospect of reacquainting themselves with opponents they routed 9-1 last November, and the fact that Wigan have conceded 10 goals in two home games does not suggest their defending has improved. One consolation for Roberto Martínez and his players may be the groin operation awaiting Jermain Defoe, who scored five of Tottenham's nine. Then again Spurs will have others ready to help themselves. An ankle injury keeps Victor Moses out of Wigan's attack. David Lacey

Chris Hughton played with Mick McCarthy with the Republic of Ireland, and is looking to follow his lead again in management. McCarthy established promoted Wolves in the Premier League last season, when they finished a comfortable 15th, and Hughton admits he would settle for that with Newcastle, who lost 3-0 to Manchester United, then hit Aston Villa for six last Sunday. In searching for consistency, Hughton has signed the Ivory Coast's Cheik Tioté, from FC Twente, and is pursuing half a dozen more reinforcements, including Robbie Keane [Spurs], Hatem Ben Arfa [Marseilles] and John Utaka [Portsmouth]. He also hopes to keep contract rebel Steven Taylor. Meanwhile, Sol Campbell is still short of match fitness and Taylor and Dan Gosling are under treatment. Wolves have signed Chelsea's Michael Mancienne on loan for a third season, and he goes straight into today's squad. Joe Lovejoy

Kevin MacDonald says he is still unsure whether or not he is interested in the Aston Villa job but the way results are going the decision is likely to be taken out of his hands. Villa's exit from the Europa League, which came on the back of a six-goal mauling at Newcastle, means that victory is imperative to try and lift the air of gloom which has descended on Villa Park. Everton, with just one point from their opening two games, have an injury doubt in captain Phil Neville, while Joseph Yobo and Yakubu Ayegbeni are out. Evan Fanning

Alex McLeish put in a word for Owen Coyle when his former Motherwell striker was a candidate for the vacant Burnley job in 2007. It is hard to fault his judgment, but his generosity has had its downsides: Birmingham were beaten twice by Coyle's teams last season, losing at Turf Moor and the Reebok Stadium. McLeish may be without James McFadden for Sunday's reunion. It is also a meeting of two unbeaten teams, each with an in-form goalkeeper: Jussi Jaaskelainen and Ben Foster both saved a penalty last Saturday. Richard Jolly

Liverpool lurched from calamity to respectability against Trabzonspor and will look to apply a similar gloss to their Premier League start against an Albion defence beaten six times when they last left the Hawthorns. Victory would be Liverpool's 2,000th in 4,223 league games and all their big guns are expected back having missed the trip to Turkey and Friday's five-hour flight home. Albion last won at Anfield when Jeff Astle secured a 1-0 victory in 1967 and they have not scored on this ground since 1985, when Garth Crooks grabbed the consolation in a 4-1 defeat for a side managed by Nobby Stiles. Andy Hunter

Last December Sunderland succumbed 4-3 at Eastlands where Roberto Mancini waited in the wings to replace the already condemned Mark Hughes. Afterwards an appalled Steve Bruce spoke eloquently, and passionately, about the need for managers to be offered time and patience. Following an indifferent opening to the season Sunderland's manager – whose decision to sell key striker Kenywne Jones to Stoke has angered many fans – must trust his board heeded those words. Most eyes may be on Mancini and his exciting, title chasing, multi-million pound imports but Bruce is currently a man under pressure. Louise Taylor

In January Arsenal disposed of Bolton twice in four days but Owen Coyle's team have begun the season looking more resilient, as their recovery in coming from 2-0 down to force a draw with Birmingham showed. With Jussi Jaaskelainen suspended Bolton will give Adam Bogdan, their Hungarian goalkeeper, his first Premier League start. Arsenal are without Theo Walcott and Robin van Persie but the return of Samir Nasri should help their attacking momentum. Bolton won well at West Ham three weeks ago but would be happy with a point at the Emirates. David Lacey

Sir Alex Ferguson's admission that United were "slaughtered" at Goodison in February may console an Everton side without a win and yet to rediscover those heights. David Moyes is not fooled. "I'm sure he said that for the benefit of his own players," said Everton's manager. "We've only beaten them once or twice in recent years." They urgently need another win to stop this campaign listing. United expect to welcome back Rio Ferdinand but Javier Hernández and Antonio Valencia did not return from international duty until late on Thursday. Andy Hunter

Few games taking place tomorrow can match the feel-good factor of this one. Both sides are undefeated and will believe goals are there to be had despite their two previous Premier League meetings at Craven Cottage ending 0-0. Fulham will look to Bobby Zamora, buoyed by signing a new four-year contract, to strike for them while Wolves will hope Sylvan Ebanks-Blake is primed to record his third goal of the campaign. They are also likely to hand Marcus Bent a debut at some point following his loan move from Birmingham. Sachin Nakrani

Manchester City could be without £80m worth of attackers and it is another embarrassment for Roque Santa Cruz, in the week he was left out of their Europa League squad in favour of the academy graduate Shaleum Logan, that Roberto Mancini is so reluctant to draft him in against his former club, even when Carlos Tevez, Emmanuel Adebayor and Mario Balotelli could all be missing. Instead, Jô is being primed for his first league start for City in almost two years, whereas Blackburn's manager, Sam Allardyce, may give Benjani Mwaruwari, another of English football's forgotten men, a debut against his old team. Daniel Taylor

Sol Campbell, Hatem Ben Arfa – aka the new Laurent Robert – and Cheick Tioté are hoping to make their Newcastle debuts but Chris Hughton may well be reluctant to disrupt his starting XI. Marlon Harewood, a loanee at St James' Park from Aston Villa last season, will aim to jog Tyneside memories with a goal while spearheading Blackpool's attack. Not that Ian Holloway is overly optimistic. "We'll be doing fantastically if we get one point from our next two games at Newcastle and Chelsea," he said. "We have to scrap, bite and kick for anything we can get." Louise Taylor

Tottenham's goalkeeper Heurelho Gomes is still out with a groin injury, so Harry Redknapp must choose whether to continue with Carlo Cudicini in goal, despite a costly mistake against Wigan, or bring in the new signing Stipe Pletikosa. Redknapp may also use the Dutch midfielder Rafael van der Vaart at some point, purchased at the last minute from Real Madrid. Albion will have some new faces in their line-up, too, with Marc-Antoine Fortuné set to make his second debut for the club after re-signing from Celtic in August. Richard Flower

West Ham have had a desperately poor start to their season and the last thing they will want to face is a Chelsea side in rampant form and scoring goals by the hatful at home and away. All may not be lost for manager Avram Grant as there is a chink of light in the darkness in the form of Frank Lampard's injury and a creaking John Terry at the heart of the Chelsea defence. Summer signing Thomas Hitzlsperger may make his long-awaited debut at Upton Park as a substitute if he can prove his fitness after a niggling thigh injury. Richard Flower

Sunderland's manager Steve Bruce will consider letting club record signing Asamoah Gyan loose on his former employers' porous defence from kick-off. Ghana's Asamoah Gyan, the £13m transfer deadline purchase from Rennes, has, according to Bruce, the perfect attributes for a Premier League striker, and will play some part. "He's fantastic in the air, quick, and he'll give so much to the team," Bruce said. Wigan, who have shipped 10 goals in two matches at the DW Stadium thus far, could give debuts to their own August acquisitions, striker Franco di Santo, the Argentine recruited from Chelsea, and on-loan Manchester United midfielder Tom Cleverley. Richard Gibson

Birmingham are hard to beat home since they returned to the top flight. In the circumstances, this fixture will be informative about Roy Hodgson's chances of rebuilding Liverpool with limited means. His side has held its own to date and new signings Raul Meireles and Paul Konchesky are in the squad. Alex McLeish, for his part, has the option of giving debuts to Jean Beausejour and Martin Jiranek, although Alexander Hleb is injured. Neither manager can spend heavily and this season will test their ingenuity as well as their eye for a bargain. Kevin McCarra

Gérard Houllier spoke endlessly today but it is the unassuming Kevin MacDonald who will take charge of Aston Villa for a sixth successive game on Monday. He will hope to build on the 1-0 win achieved over Everton before the international break and, in turn, bolster belief in the squad ahead of Houllier's eventual arrival. Stoke have the capabilities to wound the visitors, especially now Eidur Gudjohnsen has joined the ranks, and will be desperate to do so having lost all three Premier League games this season. Sachin Nakrani

With Gérard Houllier due to take over as manager after this game, Villa will want to greet him with a 100% home league record. Certainly a home win looks likely now that Bolton, already missing the suspended Jussi Jaaskelainen and Gary Cahill from their defence, could be without Kevin Davies, who is still feeling the effects of a clash of heads at Arsenal last weekend. Yet Bolton are showing more enterprise under Owen Coyle and still have the means to punish Villa if they lapse into their old habit of fading after a bright start. David Lacey

Mark Hughes returns to the club where he cut his Premier League managerial teeth still unbeaten since taking the reins at Fulham. But, following points at Bolton and Blackpool, his third trip to the north-west this season will be the most daunting. Like Hughes, Sam Allardyce secured a top-10 finish for Blackburn last season, based mainly on robust form at Ewood Park. The hosts are also seeking a 1000th top-flight victory while Fulham have not tasted league success away from Craven Cottage for 13 months. Richard Gibson

Chris Hughton is the only Premier League manager to have named the exact same starting line-up in each of his team's four matches this season but that is likely to change following last week's disappointing 2-0 defeat by Blackpool. The most notable inclusion for this game should be Sol Campbell on what will be his debut for the club. The former England defender may need all his experience against a team that has yet to come down from the high of snatching that late, thrilling draw against Manchester United a week ago. Sachin Nakrani

Some West Ham supporters may feel the timing of Yom Kippur, the Jewish holy day, to be unfortunate as it keeps their manager, Avram Grant, and the defender Tal Ben Haim away from a game they desperately need to at least draw following four defeats that has left the club in last place. Stoke's first victory of this campaign came with a rousing comeback to defeat Aston Villa 2-1 on Monday. They will fancy their chances of securing a second successive win in front of their always enthusiastic and raucous fans. Jamie Jackson

As a boyhood Arsenal fan Darren Bent would relish scoring against Arsène Wenger's side tomorrow. Bent, though, must hope Steve Bruce deploys him in attack alongside Asamoah Gyan rather than in the midfield role he occupied at Wigan last Saturday. Another sub-plot will involve the likely midfield duel between young English prospects, Arsenal's Jack Wilshere and Sunderland's Jordan Henderson. Wenger's men demolished Braga in midweek but Arsenal have a habit of losing fluency on Wearside and were defeated 1-0 in this fixture last season. Louise Taylor

Tottenham suffered a stupefying European hangover in their last home game against Wigan and have to overcome fatigue and the burden of expectation against a Wolves side who beat them twice last season. Packed midfields tend to stifle Spurs and Wolves' industrious and belligerent quartet – possibly stiffened by a fifth body tomorrow – puts the onus on Gareth Bale to find space to exploit. The visitors are as feisty as last year but not so cagey and will look to take advantage of a back-four still struggling for cohesion Rob Bagchi

Both teams come into this game on the back of encouraging displays and results last weekend. Birmingham are unbeaten, building on the ground gained last season, but none of their strikers managed a dozen league goals then, and none of them has scored yet this time, which must be a concern. West Bromwich have recovered well from their 6-0 drubbing at Chelsea on opening day, beating Sunderland and gaining a deserved draw with Spurs last week. That said, they have scored just two goals in their four league games. Graham Dorrans is available again but James Morrison is still suspended. Joe Lovejoy

Chelsea have scored 17 goals in four league games this season and that has been against teams trying to defend. Blackpool, in contrast, have shown a surprising commitment to attack on their Premier League debut and it will be fascinating to see if they repeat that against the champions. Last month's 6-0 thrashing at Arsenal may persuade Ian Holloway, the Blackpool manager, to be cautious but either way it is hard not to see the hosts, rampant in Europe as well as at home, winning a sixth straight game in handsome style. Sachin Nakrani

It has been a low-key start by Manchester United. Time is on their side, but it would be irksome to Sir Alex Ferguson if Chelsea's four-point lead over them was extended this weekend. Liverpool come to Old Trafford happy with the 4-1 victory over Steaua Bucharest in the Europa League, particularly since Jamie Carragher, Fernando Torres, Steven Gerrard and others did not take part. Roy Hodgson's side, whose last league match was the goalless draw away to Birmingham, should be fresh and awkward opponents. Kevin McCarra

Roberto Mancini cannot feel totally secure at the richly ambitious Manchester City following a run of one win in their opening four league fixtures and it will not please him to know that the club have never won a Premier League game at Wigan. The visitors are, though, favourites to triumph, even more so after their assured victory in Salzburg on Thursday. The hosts, who have yet to win at the DW Stadium this campaign, can take heart from their recent win at Tottenham and last week's draw with Sunderland. Sachin Nakrani

Arsenal have scored 16 times in their first three home games and whatever team they put out at the Emirates promises an abundance of goals. So West Bromwich will not be taking too much notice of Arsène Wenger's lengthening casualty list, although the absence of Cesc Fábregas always gives opponents fresh hope. Abou Diaby, Tomas Rosicky and Emmanuel Eboué are Arsenal's other doubts, while Albion will be hoping that any confidence engendered by last Saturday's recovery to beat Birmingham is still there. David Lacey

After both sides successfully navigated their way through the Carling Cup in midweek, all eyes will be on Birmingham as they attempt to take their unbeaten home record past the 12-month mark. Not since Bolton were victorious there in September last year have Blues' supporters seen their team defeated at St Andrew's – a run that will stretch to 18 Premier League games if they manage at least a point tomorrow. Wigan may only have won once in the league this season but it came in impressive style at Tottenham last month. Mehreen Khan

For two clubs so close geographically there has been little to connect them in recent years and this is their first league fixture since a Division Three meeting 30 years ago. One denominator is Sam Allardyce, whose managerial aspirations have grown since his start with Blackpool in 1994, a two-season stint which flirted with promotion to the second tier. Blackpool's home form will determine whether they remain in the top flight and this is only their second Premier League fixture at the revamped Bloomfield Road. Richard Gibson

Fulham are still unbeaten in the league although four of those games ended in draws and they come into this one on the back of a 2-0 loss at Stoke in the Carling Cup, which also cost them their top-scorer, Moussa Dembélé, for three weeks. David Moyes began his Everton reign with a win against the Londoners but despite a return of two points from five games and the fans wondering if he will ever field two strikers on the same pitch again, most would settle for a point after the midweek disaster just up the river at Brentford. Mark Tallentire

Anfield's status as a venue of high emotion will be apparent tomorrow. Supporters plan to protest during and after the game at the draining saga that is the ownership of the club while the team looks to recover from the midweek humiliation to Northampton Town. Few, if any, of those defeated on Wednesday will feature against Sunderland but, nonetheless, there will be a duty on those that do play to show character. The visitors arrive with injury concerns but their belief enhanced thanks to last Saturday's draw with Arsenal. Sachin Nakrani

Sir Alex Ferguson questioned this week whether Chelsea had been allowed to select their own fixture list, commenting upon the "very easy" nature of their opponents, and a visit to Eastlands certainly represents the most difficult test yet for the champions. City beat them twice last season but the home side are badly undermined by an injury list that will deprive Roberto Mancini of all but one full-back. Chelsea, too, have players missing after the midweek defeat to Newcastle United but their injury issues are not so serious and they are bound to cause problems for an experimental City defence. Daniel Taylor

After securing their first point of the season last week, West Ham will be hoping to catch Tottenham off guard as Harry Redknapp's men may have one eye on their first Champions League home game of the season, against FC Twente on Wednesday. Avram Grant will be back in the West Ham dugout having missed last week's draw at Stoke due to Yom Kippur and will want to inspire his team to their first victory of the season. West Ham, though, have not beaten Spurs since a win at Upton Park on the last day of the 2005-06 season. Saad Noor

It had been a low-profile start to the campaign for Owen Coyle until Bolton lost in the Carling Cup to his former team Burnley before a vengeful Turf Moor. The Premier League, by contrast, has been rather quite for him, with three draws in five matches. The one victory came at West Ham at the end of last month and it is also the opposition who carry expectations, even if Coyle's side is at home. Manchester United have not yet hit their very best form and must also have Wednesday's Champions League tie in Valencia on their mind. Kevin McCarra

Both Chris Hughton and Tony Pulis are likely to switch back to Premier League mode after making wholesale changes for their club's respective Carling Cup victories in midweek. Tim Krul will continue in goal for Newcastle following the news that Steve Harper is scheduled to miss up to 12 weeks of action with the shoulder injury he sustained during last week's win at Everton. Stoke also have injury concerns, with Kenwyne Jones, Jon Walters and Jermaine Pennant all doubts ahead of their visit to St James' Park. Lance Harvey

After getting off to a winning start on Wednesday in his first game as Aston Villa manager, Gérard Houllier takes charge of his first Premier League match for six years in this West Midlands derby. Richard Dunne is ruled out with a knee injury and Stephen Ireland is doubtful, although Houllier's main selection dilemma surrounds whether to start with Emile Heskey after his impressive impact in midweek. Wolves have no new injury worries as they look for their first league win since the opening day of the season. Stuart James

It is Everton's turn to try and end Birmingham's impressive home record – Alex McLeish's side have now gone a year without suffering defeat at St Andrew's – and there may be a hint of desperation to the visitors' approach. Much was expected of Everton ahead of the new season but they find themselves in last place after a run of six games without victory and will be keen to generate some momentum ahead of the Merseyside derby in a fortnight's time. Tony Hibbert may return for Everton having missed last week's stalemate at Fulham with a groin injury but Louis Saha remains unavailable. Sachin Nakrani

Tony Pulis and Sam Allardyce have seen an upturn in fortunes over the past few weeks and will be looking for their sides to pull further clear of the scrap developing below them. Stoke will be aiming to stretch a four-game unbeaten run and have been boosted by the news that Ricardo Fuller could be set for a place on the bench after scans revealed no fracture to his shoulder. However, Jermaine Pennant and Andy Wilkinson are major doubts for the Potters. Blackburn, who have won only six out of 32 league games on the road under Allardyce, welcome back Jason Roberts and Keith Andrews to the squad for the trip to the Britannia. Oliver Yew

Since becoming a manager Steve Bruce has never beaten Sir Alex Ferguson but the former Manchester United captain's Sunderland side have a habit of rising to the occasion and tend to give the top teams decent games on Wearside. Ferguson could well cast covetous eyes at Jordan Henderson, Bruce's bright young England Under-21 midfielder. Meanwhile, Scotland fans will be intrigued to see whether the newly fit Craig Gordon regains his place in the home goal following some excellent performances from his Belgian understudy Simon Mignolet. Louise Taylor

For Tottenham at the moment every game is a test for their injury-stricken defence and although Aston Villa may be without Gabriel Agbonlahor, nursing a groin strain, Gérard Houllier's successful resurrection of Emile Heskey could be a major factor today. Heskey will be seeking a third goal in successive matches, as opposed to successive seasons, while Spurs will hope that Rafael van der Vaart again gives them the drive which did for Twente in the Champions League in midweek. Richard Dunne is fit to return to Villa's back four if Houllier feels he needs him. David Lacey

Both Albion's Roberto Di Matteo and Bolton's Owen Coyle have warned their club's supporters not to get carried away with what have been unexpectedly successful starts to the season, but this promises to be a entertaining encounter between two confident and attractive teams. Albion look infinitely better organised than the team which finished bottom two seasons ago, while Bolton under Coyle have added an effective passing element to the direct football which, while ensuring their continued presence in the top flight, tended to make them very hard to watch. Richard Rae

Few would blame Clint Dempsey for a speculative shot on goal at some point tomorrow, with the Fulham forward no doubt keen to reprise the moment in June when he turned Rob Green into a laughing stock. The West Ham goalkeeper was outstanding in last week's win over Tottenham Hotspur, and has already been tipped by his manager Avram Grant for an England recall. That may be every bit as premature as the view that after three fine results West Ham are out of trouble. Fulham, unbeaten but with only one win, could be deadly if they find a goalscorer. James Callow

Roberto Martínez, the Wigan manager, has spoken of the healthy competition among his goalkeepers, with Omani Ali Al Habsi proving a fine understudy to the injured Chris Kirkland. Yet the blanks at the other end threaten to define Wigan's prospects, having failed to score in four of their six matches. Wolves' fine start to the season has since sagged under the weight of opponents' late goals: level going into the final five minutes of their last three league contests, they have lost the lot and a fourth consecutive reverse would equal their worst Premier League run. Richard Gibson

Last season's convincing wins for Chelsea over Arsenal gave the impression of a gulf between the sides, but Arsène Wenger's team had recorded victories against them in each of the two preceding campaigns. Both sides will lack established players, notably Frank Lampard and Cesc Fábregas, but the real trouble for the visitors lies in the absence of the injured Thomas Vermaelen. It was bad enough for Arsenal even when their best centre-half was in the line-up, with Didier Drogba scoring four goals in the past two encounters. Kevin McCarra

Not even in their darkest hour this summer could Liverpool have envisaged hosting Blackpool in October with one less point, fewer goals scored and with as many shots on target (23) as Ian Holloway's rapidly-assembled side. But that is the reality confronting Roy Hodgson. It is a matter of conjecture as to which team has shown the greater ambition. Liverpool have faced a difficult start but concern over performance level is justified, and it will be expected to improve significantly against a Blackpool team with two valuable away wins to their name this season. Having appeared in discomfort at the end of Thursday's draw in Utrecht, Fernando Torres is fit and available. Andy Hunter

Manchester City have conceded only two goals in their opening six Premier League games and anything but a home victory would represent a surprise here even if Newcastle can be encouraged by the fact they won their last away game at Everton. Newcastle have not beaten City on their own ground since Alan Shearer scored the winner in a 1-0 victory at Maine Road in September 2000 and, if they are to end that run, they may have to monitor Carlos Tevez closely – the Argentinian has scored four of his side's seven league goals so far. Daniel Taylor

Given these teams' recent histories, which featured Eduardo Da Silva's broken leg following a tackle by Martin Taylor at Birmingham two years ago, plus the ongoing controversy regarding questionable challenges, this contest should make fascinating viewing. Especially as each side suffered reverses in their previous Premier League outing a fortnight ago, when Arsenal were defeated 2-0 at Chelsea and Birmingham lost by the same score at home to Everton. Arsène Wenger's side also require victory to convince they can still be credible title challengers this season. Jamie Jackson

This has the potential to be an awkward fixture for Chelsea. Carlo Ancelotti is without Didier Drogba, Frank Lampard, Saloman Kalou and Alex for a trip to a stadium where Chelsea have generally struggled. Villa, who will again be without the injured Gabriel Agbonlahor, should have plenty of motivation after Chelsea won 7-1 at Stamford Bridge last season and also defeated them 3-0 in the FA Cup semi-finals a couple of weeks later. Much could depend on whether the rejuvenated Emile Heskey can continue his excellent recent form. Stuart James

Three wins in four games has left Stoke an impressive seventh, but Tony Pulis was forced to defend his methods after being one of the managers singled out by Fulham's Danny Murphy for sending their teams out to stop the opposition. The Potters are unlikely to change what clearly works but Owen Coyle has made Bolton much easier to watch and just needs to start converting draws into wins to make an important point. The Trotters manager will be hoping the combative striker Kevin Davies can shake off the ankle knock he suffered on England duty. Richard Rae

Fulham are still unbeaten in the league, albeit with one win and six draws, while Wednesday's Champions League trip to Milan to face Internazionale will not be far from Tottenham's thoughts. So if there is to be winner it is more likely to be Mark Hughes's team, although another draw looks the safer bet. The visitors will look to Rafael van der Vaart carrying on where he left off against Aston Villa a fortnight ago and Harry Redknapp must be relieved that his injury-stricken defence will be spared the attentions of Bobby Zamora, recovering from a broken leg. David Lacey

Whatever the true state of Wayne Rooney's ankle, Albion are likely to be without their own first-choice centre-forward as Peter Odemwingie is struggling to shake off a knee injury while Jerome Thomas is also doubtful. Theoretically, this should be straightforward for Manchester United, who have not dropped a league point at Old Trafford this season. Nevertheless, Roberto Di Matteo's first four away games have taken him to the old Big Four. They were first thrashed at Chelsea, pushed Liverpool hard and then shocked Arsenal. Tim Rich

The loss of France international Hatem Ben Arfa will be acutely felt by Newcastle United, although it gives Wayne Routledge yet another chance to prove he is good enough to play in the Premier League. The winger has failed to convince so far, but the long-term injury to Ben Arfa means he will get another run in the side. Andy Carroll's international ambition is being hampered by the loss of his place in the starting lineup at club level and he is likely to lose out to Shola Ameobi again. Wigan's Charles N'Zogbia, who had a training ground punch-up with Carroll during his time on Tyneside, can expect a hot reception on his first return to St James' Park. Lance Harvey

Wolves' official website yesterday welcomed visitors with an invitation to purchase a pair of golden "lucky pants". Desperate times call for desperate measures. Four successive defeats mean Wanderers are bottom of the Premier League, propping up their 19th-placed visitors on goal difference. Mick McCarthy has admitted it is a "huge game" for the club and called for "solidarity" in the face of recent criticism. They will need that and more against an improving Hammers side who could welcome back Valon Behrami, Radoslav Kovac and Kieron Dyer. John Ashdown

Malcolm Allison once said that Manchester City would be the first club to play on Mars; they have not quite managed it but they are at least looking upwards as they arrive in Blackpool. Roberto Mancini's team have moved to second in the league and even Gary Neville has described them in the last week as genuine title candidates. Blackpool's impressive start to the season suggests they cannot be underestimated, even if this is a contest between the richest and poorest clubs in the Premier League and Ian Holloway will be missing from the home dug-out, serving a one-match ban for abusing the referee Mike Dean during the home defeat to Blackburn Rovers last month. Daniel Taylor

Everton have not beaten Liverpool in the league since September 2006. There could hardly be a more favourable moment to break that run, because the Anfield side's poor form has left them in the bottom three, even if they will have been lifted by the completion of the club's sale to new US owners. The form of the Goodison club has barely been better than that of the visitors and they stand above them in the table purely on goal difference, but all the organisational and motivational skills of the manager Roy Hodgson will be needed. Kevin McCarra

Asamoah Gyan is expected to start as a lone striker for Sunderland as Darren Bent is struggling with a groin injury suffered while on international duty. Craig Gordon will return to the squad after a long absence but seems unlikely to dislodge Simon Mignolet as first-choice just yet. David Dunn, Blackburn's top scorer last season, could be involved at some stage despite the hamstring problem that has limited him to two appearances so far in 2010-11 but Keith Andrews and Vince Grella are both definitely out of contention Richard Flower

Birmingham manager Alex McLeish was angry when his team were booed off after their year-long unbeaten run at home was ended by Everton three weeks ago, but concern about the team's uninspired performances this season have been growing at St Andrew's for some time. Two goals in their last five games is symptomatic of a disturbing lack of creativity on the part of the Blues, and the rumblings will grow in volume if Blackpool, who are guaranteed to attack in reckless numbers, add to their impressive total of three away wins. Richard Rae

These are tricky times for Wolves. Mick McCarthy's side have not won a league game since the opening day and collide with Manchester City, Manchester United and Arsenal in their three matches after tomorrow's trip to the champions. It must be hard to see light at the end of the tunnel. Their last victory at Stamford Bridge came 31 years ago, and they conceded nine on their last two league visits. They must cling to the possibility that Chelsea's players will be sluggish having not returned to Cobham from Moscow until 3.30am on Wednesday. A difficult afternoon awaits. Dominic Fifield

Sunderland are unbeaten in the league for two months but five of their last six games have ended in stalemate and there is a pressing need to turn draws into wins. The paradox is that while Steve Bruce's new 4-5-1 formation has afforded his team the division's third best defensive record its installation has prompted a goal drought. One of three sides to win at the Stadium of Light last season, Villa will aim to deny Simon Mignolet, Sunderland's Belgian Under-21 goalkeeper who continues to keep Scotland's Craig Gordon on the bench, a third straight clean sheet. Might Villa's Stewart Downing, impressive here during a loan stint from Middlesbrough, remind Wearside of his talent? Louise Taylor

Last weekend's assured victory over Liverpool, and the 2-0 win at Birmingham which preceded, it will have perked Everton up considerably following another slow start and they will be ready to prey on any after-effects Spurs are suffering as a result of Wednesday's first-half mauling by Internazionale. David Moyes may have lost Leon Osman with an ankle injury but Everton still have the wit and pace in attack to punish any further lapses by Tottenham's weakened defence. At the same time Rafael Van der Vaart, suspended in Milan, should be back for Spurs. David Lacey

Fulham, already deprived of their main striker, Bobby Zamora, will be without their entire first-choice midfield. They will miss the creative influences of Danny Murphy, Damien Duff and Simon Davies, while an injury to the more defensive-minded Dickson Etuhu undermines their chances further. Those absentees mean former West Bromwich players Diomansy Kamara, Zoltan Gera and Jonathan Greening may all start. The managers, Roberto Di Matteo and Mark Hughes, used to be room-mates at Chelsea. John Stanton

West Ham United are unbeaten in four Premier League games, their best since run April 2009 vindicating Avram Grant's early season assertion that once winter arrived so would his team's form. Newcastle United side last won on 18 September, and come to east London with a troubled Andy Carroll, whose week has so far featured an assault charge and the torching of his £150,000 Range Rover. Matthew Upson could face a late fitness test on a neck injury while Newcastle could be shorthanded in defence. Jamie Jackson

For a side that has won only two games this season, there is an awful lot of confidence about Bolton – based on a series of highly impressive draws. After his remarkable late intervention against Stoke, which saw him come on as a substitute, score the winner and then get himself sent off for two bookable offences, Ivan Klasnic is suspended for the short journey to the DW Stadium. Since the on-loan Ali Al Habsi is ineligible to face Bolton, Roberto Martínez will recall Chris Kirkland, who began the season by conceding four against Blackpool and six against Chelsea. However, Martinez was at pains to point out that the man who began the season as Wigan's first choice keeper and captain was not fully fit for those encounters. Tim Rich

Roy Hodgson believes he was unfairly dismissed after 17 months at Blackburn in the 1990s but he knows how intense the pressure will be should he fail to win his 17th game in charge of Liverpool. Thursday's goalless draw with Napoli brought much-needed respite for the Liverpool manager as his team were organised, cohesive and resilient on a night when he gambled by leaving four first-team regulars at home. Anyone recalled against Rovers - regardless of their stature - owes Hodgson a performance against a Blackburn side that has problems in defence but will be looking to capitalise on Liverpool's growing anxiety. Andy Hunter

Manchester City may just be coming to terms with the great means they possess. In early autumn their impressive squad did not prevent them from losing 1-0 away to Sunderland before being held to a draw at Eastlands by Blackburn Rovers. There is more vibrancy to their play now, but Roberto Mancini will be aware that he cannot allow a team like Arsenal too much scope to express themselves and this game could resemble that gruelling encounter against Chelsea last month, which City won 1-0. Kevin McCarra

Tony Pulis believes that Wayne Rooney's surprise decision to sign a new contract will give Manchester United "a hell of a lift" ahead of their visit to the Britannia Stadium . "It is not good for us, obviously," the Stoke manager said. "Everyone at United will now be able to focus. If they win the title this season, this could be the moment they look back on in May and realise that was where it changed." Rooney is expected to miss this fixture through injury while Pulis will wait on the fitness of the striker, Ricardo Fuller. Stuart James

Arsenal often bring out the best in West Ham so it would be wrong to regard this meeting of second against bottom as a foregone conclusion. That said, Arsenal have already scored 25 goals at the Emirates this season while West Ham's defence continues to look a thing of shreds and patches. West Ham will have taken some heart from their Carling Cup comeback against Stoke but Arsenal, facing a long trip to Donetsk in the Champions League, will want to get the game wrapped up quickly so they can rest their legs. David Lacey

If plans to rename Ewood Park after a sponsor come to fruition, Blackburn might hope it brings them better luck against Chelsea, who have lost here only once in 13 years – and that when they had already secured the title. With only one home win all season, Blackburn face a Chelsea side who have scored 17 more goals in their nine matches. At least the manager, Sam Allardyce, should have his first choice central defence with Chris Samba returning from suspension and Ryan Nelsen from a thigh injury. For Chelsea, Alex should have recovered from a hip problem in time to partner John Terry. Tim Rich

This is a contest between the slow starters and the vulnerable finishers: Everton have picked up after surprising early losses, mirroring their two previous Premier League campaigns, while Stoke's own improvement has been tainted by conceding goals in the final seven minutes of their last three matches, the most recent in midweek Carling Cup elimination at West Ham. Jermaine Pennant and Kenwyne Jones were both forced off in the second half of that 3-1 defeat with a virus which jeopardises their participation. Injuries have decimated Everton's midfield but they have not lost to Stoke for 28 years. Richard Gibson

Tube station closures mean fans will be heading to Craven Cottage via distant Hammersmith, and it's likely that no one will have a spring in their step – the last 10 meetings between these sides have produced 14 goals. Fulham have won once in the league all season, while Wigan's current form can be spun either way – four games without defeat (their best since February 2009) or, for those with glasses half empty, one win in six. "It's that point of the season when the performances are more important than results," said Roberto Martínez. Still, a victory would no doubt be welcome. John Ashdown

Manchester United are the only unbeaten side in the division but are five points behind Chelsea, largely because Sir Alex Ferguson's team have already drawn more games than in the whole of last season. Tottenham have gone 25 games without beating United in all competitions, their last victory at Old Trafford all the way back in 1989, a 1-0 win courtesy of Gary Lineker. Wayne Rooney will be absent again for the home side but that is not as significant a setback as it would have been this time last year and the biggest threat to Spurs may be Javier Hernández, with three goals in the last week. Daniel Taylor

Mick McCarthy has developed an uncharacteristic sense of adventure over the last month but a failure to convert chances has prevented Wolves from turning good performances into points. With Matthew Jarvis seemingly getting better every week, and Stephen Hunt in line to make his long-awaited first home start, Wolves can be confident of again making opportunities, even more so if the manager goes with the inventive Nenad Milijas in midfield instead of the enforcer Karl Henry. Carlos Tevez is not fit to play for the visitors, so Wolves may only have to take one of their chances to finally reverse a trend that is beginning to alarm. Paul Doyle

The 119th derby match in all competitions between these clubs and the incentive for Birmingham could hardly be greater. A victory would not only lift them above Aston Villa in the league table but also bring to an end a humiliating run of six straight defeats at the hands of their local rivals. Marc Albrighton is suspended for Villa, meaning that Ashley Young is likely to revert to the flank. Birmingham are boosted by Craig Gardner's return from a three-match ban, the midfielder one of three former Villa players in Alex McLeish's squad. Stuart James

The points and the performance against Blackburn alleviated pressure on Roy Hodgson last weekend but one win is not a cure-all. A trip to Bolton, unbeaten in four league games at home this season, represents a truer test of Liverpool's improvement. The visitors have won just one of their last 13 away league games while Hodgson's individual record is even worse. He has not presided over a league win away from home since Fulham beat Portsmouth on the opening day of last season. Johan Elmander is in rich form for Owen Coyle's side, although all five of his goals have come on Bolton's travels. Andy Hunter

Growing up in Wallsend Steve Bruce was a diehard Newcastle United supporter who would later dismay his family by twice turning down the chance to become manager at St James' Park before eventually winding up at Sunderland. Incredibly, Bruce has never been to a north-east derby in any capacity before and says he "can't wait". Chris Hughton, meanwhile, will be praying for the win which would bolster his seemingly fragile job security. Sub-plots abound with two of the most notable seeing Titus Bramble return to Newcastle in a Sunderland shirt and Joey Barton and Lee Cattermole reviving a wince inducing central midfield rivalry. Louise Taylor

Roberto Di Matteo, the West Bromwich manager, has described Monday's opponents Blackpool as "the most attractive team in the Premier League after Arsenal and Chelsea". Quite a compliment from a man whose side have won plaudits themselves for an aesthetically pleasing style of play that has seen them climb to sixth in the table. If this match is anything like the clashes between these sides in the Championship last season, it could prove to be a treat for the neutrals, providing Blackpool can put aside the distraction caused by Charlie Adam's contract rumpus. Richard Flower

Surely something has to give, or rather improve, at St Andrew's where Birmingham, with one win in their last seven Premier League games, meet West Ham, with one win all season. A goalless draw is probably a decent bet, with both teams crying out for a productive striker. Craig Gardner, a midfielder, is the Blues's leading scorer with three in the league, which explains their interest in Cardiff's Jay Bothroyd. Nobody has managed more than Mark Noble's two for the Hammers, and he is missing today after appendix surgery. Opposing centre-halves Roger Johnson [ankle] and Matthew Upson [hamstring] will both have late fitness tests. West Ham's Julian Faubert is suspended. Joe Lovejoy

Blackburn's relatively rude health during Sam Allardyce's 23-month tenure as manager has been founded on home comfort but not since the opening day of the season have they won a Premier League contest at Ewood Park, a four-match sequence which equals their worst under Allardyce and has plunged them into the bottom three. Roberto Martínez's Wigan, one place above Rovers, have improved since shipping 10 goals across the opening two weekends and are mean-spirited on their travels, having conceded only four times in as many top-flight games. However, they are winless in all seven previous visits to their Lancashire rivals. Richard Gibson

Monday's victory over a West Brom team reduced to nine men for much of the game left Blackpool ninth in the table, but a lot of managers will have noted the Seasiders were tactically exposed at Birmingham in their previous match. Steadily improving Everton are at their most effective playing on the break, and may make Ian Holloway's team pay for their admirable willingness to commit numbers in attack. Much may depend on the state of mind of Charlie Adam; that Blackpool should be embroiled in a financial dispute over a relatively small bonus payment with their outstanding player does not bode well. Richard Rae

A penny for Gretar Steinsson's thoughts. The Bolton right-back is an accomplished performer but he must be dreading the prospect of facing Gareth Bale following his display in Tottenham's 3-1 win over Internazionale on Tuesday. The Welshman humiliated Maicon and, as such, will be confident of causing Steinsson even greater distress today. Bolton, however, can take heart from Spurs' injury list, which now includes Rafael van der Vaart, and the fact they have never won a Premier League match away to today's hosts. Sachin Nakrani

With Emile Heskey joining their list of stricken strikers Villa may ask the England Under-21 striker Nathan Delfouneso to lead the attack. So the chances of Gérard Houllier's team improving on their modest league total of nine goals appear limited. Fulham have also been short of experienced finishers although Andy Johnson's brief reappearance against Wigan last weekend suggested the problem was easing. Either way this is unlikely to be a goal-fest and one will probably be enough to decide it assuming either side get that far. David Lacey

For the first time in four visits to Old Trafford, Wolves' manager Mick McCarthy will play his first-choice side. Twice, he changed personnel for the Carling Cup and was rewarded with narrow defeats. Last season he made 10 changes in order to prioritise a game against Burnley and was given a suspended £25,000 fine that still rankles. It is, however, 30 years since Wolves gained so much as a point at Manchester United, who are likely to have Darren Fletcher back from an ankle injury, although Nani and Ryan Giggs are rested ahead of Wednesday's Manchester derby. Tim Rich

The last thing Steve Bruce probably needs after last Sunday's 5-1 hammering at Newcastle is coming face to face with a Stoke side featuring former Sunderland players with points to prove. Foremost among them is Kenwyne Jones, the Trindidad and Tobago striker whose switch to the Potteries was precipitated by a falling-out with Bruce. Then there is the ex-Sunderland captain Dean Whitehead. How he will relish his likely duel with the man who replaced him, Lee Cattermole. It will be intriguing to see whether Bruce manages to accommodate Asamoah Gyan, his Ghana striker and record £13m signing in today's starting line up. Meanwhile the home defence will need to be mindful of a renascent Tuncay Sanli. Louise Taylor

Arsène Wenger says that Newcastle's destruction of Sunderland last week may have been to his advantage, as it helped warn his players against treating the Geordies with the sort of complacency that has this season led to defeats by West Brom and Shakhtar. Being forewarned may not be forearmed when it comes to dealing with Andy Carroll, however, and the young striker has the tools to test the solidity of Arsenal's central defence. Pass that test and Arsenal can count on the rest of the team passing Newcastle to death. Paul Doyle

By beating Napoli Liverpool ran up three consecutive wins for the first time since September of last year. They did so with a hat-trick from the substitute Steven Gerrard. That dependence on him can be a concern, but there is also relief that he has such impact. With Fernando Torres enhancing the line-up further, this could be the most demanding fixture the visitors have had so far this season. The champions, however, did conserve energy in Wednesday's routine 4-1 defeat of Spartak Moscow. Kevin McCarra

Roberto Mancini would like to portray himself as impervious to angst but the Manchester City manager will surely note the contrast in fortunes between himself and his West Brom counterpart and countryman Roberto di Matteo. West Brom have won goodwill with their attractive and productive football this season, to the extent of which they emerged in credit from defeat by Blackpool on Monday. Mancini, on the other hand, may feel the world urging him to fail, while his highly-strung players are finding new ways to lose games. James Callow

Sir Alex Ferguson will not want another draw today. Villa look like being without eight of their first-team squad and will again look to the youngsters who went close to victory at Fulham before scraping a late winner against Blackpool's occasionals. With Chelsea quick to resume winning habits after losing at Anfield, United cannot afford to drop points in games they are expected to win, and Villa can expect them to throw men forward more quickly than they did at Eastlands. Villa's youthful lack of inhibition could be their biggest asset. David Lacey

Roberto Mancini has taken umbrage about the allegation that his tactics are too conservative for a side with title aspirations, but Manchester City have scored fewer goals than newly promoted Blackpool and West Bromwich Albion and are fourth largely due to the fact Joe Hart, on loan at Birmingham last season, has already kept four clean sheets. Mancini's men were happy with a 0-0 draw against a Manchester United side missing several key players in midweek, but the dynamicswill be different on Saturday and the onus will be on them to attack a side that have slipped to 17th, only one point off the relegation zone. Daniel Taylor

Joey Barton's midweek misdemeanour against Blackburn Rovers was the latest needless distraction from a largely excellent start to the season for Newcastle. The midfielder has been a key component of Chris Hughton's side and will be sorely missed. Fulham's away record – no Premier League win in 15 months – remains an embarrassment but they will hope to take advantage of Newcastle's frailties at home. This is the one ground where the Cottagers have flourished in recent years, winning on three of their last five visits. John Stanton

Ten years ago this month, Liverpool came to the Britannia Stadium and scored eight and it says something for Stoke's revival since that three of the past four encounters between these sides have been drawn. Roy Hodgson should be able to draw on reinforcements with Sotirios Kyrgiakos and Joe Cole likely to return from injury or illness. Raúl Meireles, who was withdrawn after a bout of sickness during Wednesday's 1-1 draw at Wigan, will also be assessed. Having prevented a run of five successive defeats in midweek, Stoke manager Tony Pulis will have Ryan Shawcross back from a one-match suspension. Tim Rich

When you have beaten the European champions and set yourself fair to qualify for the Champions League last 16 in your debut campaign, it feels a little harsh to be criticised for a run of patchy Premier League form. Yet Tottenham's recent return of two points from an available 12 has led to one or two grumbles, much to Harry Redknapp's annoyance, and he knows that they will intensify should his team fail to beat Blackburn, who are on a high after their wins over Wigan and Newcastle. Football is a harsh old game. David Hytner

West Ham's defence has been dodgy for a long time now and the lack of solidity has infected the whole team with a dose of the jitters, which makes mistakes frequent and holding on to a lead almost impossible. Blackpool, by contrast, have been fearless since their promotion and look well armed to exploit their hosts' frailties, especially since key players were given a day off in midweek and missed the defeat at Aston Villa. There should be goals in this game, with the Hammers unlikely to get more than the visitors. Paul Doyle

The showdown between the Premier League's two youngest managers. Yet both have been around long enough to recognise that substance not style is the key. Roberto Martínez's Wigan have lost only three times in 10 fairly polished displays but have still slipped back into the drop zone. "Home games are the diamonds of your season," Martínez, no doubt wary this will be the Latics' eighth in a lop-sided start, said. Meanwhile, Albion's Roberto Di Matteo, at 40 three years Martínez's senior, has seen his newly-promoted team nosedive from fourth to the bottom half in three winless weeks. Richard Gibson

For Owen Coyle there has been an ominous lining to the silver cloud of Bolton's recent effervescent form. Both Johan Elmander and Gary Cahill have been linked with moves away with chairman Phil Gartside revealing that the club's debt has risen to £93m. "These are the type of players I want at this football club," Coyle said yesterday. "They all look to be happy in their work." Elmander is still suffering with the virus that forced him off against Everton in midweek so Ivan Klasnic may come in. Mick McCarthy's options may be limited by fresh injury worries. Dave Edwards has a thigh strain, Stephen Ward has a gashed shin courtesy of Cesc Fábregas and Kevin Doyle has a broken hand. Barney Ronay

It did not have the air of a good week for Chelsea even if they did recover from defeat at Anfield to stretch their lead over Manchester United in the Premier League to four points. Carlos Ancelotti's side scored just once to beat Fulham on Wednesday and the following day the assistant manager Ray Wilkins had gone from the club. Chelsea do have the opportunity to steady themselves against Sunderland at Stamford Bridge, but some veteran players will have to confirm in the weeks ahead that the team can sustain impetus. Kevin McCarra

Their latest "must-win" accomplished at Molineux on Wednesday, Arsenal's next awkward away date should at least be faced with confidence given events at Goodison last season. Everton suffered the worst opening day result in their history and their heaviest home defeat since 1958. "There were reasons for that," grimaced David Moyes (translation – Joleon Lescott was pushing to double his money at Manchester City). Everton have resembled Arsenal-lite this season with their over-elaboration in front of goal and will miss the foolishly suspended Marouane Fellaini. Andy Hunter

Arsenal, thanks to the early kick-off, will lead the Premier League for at least a couple of hours if they beat Tottenham. Considering that Arsène Wenger's side still have the potential to improve they ought to be genuine contenders for the prize, but the flaws have already seen them beaten at home by West Bromwich and Newcastle. Tottenham, who last kept a clean sheet in the league on the opening day of the season, have been affected by injury. They also have a poor record at Arsenal, having not won there since 1993. Kevin McCarra

Chelsea may be off the top by the time they take the field at St Andrew's today. Either way Birmingham will approach them as warily as a hunter stalks a wounded prey. Beaten twice in three games and with their team ravaged by injuries, especially at the back, Carlo Ancelotti's side have the chance to show what champions are made of. Birmingham also have problems, with Lee Bowyer standing by to replace Craig Gardner, who has an ankle injury. Alex McLeish badly needs a win but would take a repeat of last season's 0-0 draw. David Lacey

Fittingly, change will be the order of the day at Bloomfield Road. Blackpool, whose manager Ian Holloway faces sanction for making 10 of them in the recent Premier League game at Aston Villa, have not defeated Wolves for 42 years. Their efforts to overturn that statistic will not include goalkeeper Matt Gilks, who is definitely sidelined with a broken kneecap, so Richard Kingson is expected to start. Wolves will attempt to halt their trend of conceding – without a clean sheet all season, they also sport the division's worst away form. Richard Gibson

If Andy Carroll's groin allows him to start following a credible England debut against France on Wednesday, his performance against a high-flying Bolton will throw further light on just how good he may be. Owen Coyle's team are fifth and know victory against Chris Hughton's side – who are only a point behind on 18 – by a margin of three goals will allow Bolton to move beyond Manchester City into a Champions League berth. The hosts' cause will be aided by the absence of suspended Newcastle midfielders Joey Barton and Cheik Tioté. Jamie Jackson

According to Roy Hodgson it is the media that has sullied his relationship with Liverpool supporters, not the woeful performances against the likes of Blackpool and Stoke that preceded calls for the return of Kenny Dalglish. He may believe Anfield is full of journalists should Liverpool fail to prosper against the league's bottom club on Saturday. West Ham have not won here since Geoff Hurst and Martin Peters scored in a 2-1 victory in September 1963 and, for all the controversy over Steven Gerrard's injury, the visitors will feel the greater loss should Scott Parker miss out due to a chest infection. Andy Hunter

Sir Alex Ferguson says Wayne Rooney will probably be among the substituteson Saturday, the Manchester United striker preparing to make his first appearance since the mutinous contract dispute that made him richer by bank balance but a good sight poorer when it comes to reputation. Rooney or not, anything but a straightforward home victory would represent a considerable surprise, even if Dimitar Berbatov has been distinctly off-form since his hat-trick against Liverpool and Ferguson admitted in midweek they could have lost by six at Aston Villa last Saturday. Daniel Taylor

There is nothing to choose from these two – apart from form. Both are mid-table, with 16 points from 13 games, but while Stoke have won their last two, including an impressive victory over Liverpool, their opponents have taken a solitary point from their last four matches. Albion need to beware the resurgent Kenwyne Jones, outstanding against Liverpool, and will be glad to have Gonzalo Jara available again after a three-match ban, but they could be without the influential Chris Brunt, injured on international duty with Northern Ireland. Stoke will probably be unchanged. Joe Lovejoy

Having seen a bunch of raw recruits perform manfully in the draw against Manchester United, Gérard Houllier may give the 37-year-old Robert Pires his first Premier League game since leaving Arsenal four years ago. If he does, it will be on a ground where Villa have won four of their previous five fixtures. With Blackburn having won just two games at Ewood and Villa with one away win all season, this will be an afternoon of moveable objects meeting resistible forces and, although Brett Emerton may miss out, Blackburn should have El Hadji Diouf back to face the man who brought him to English football. Tim Rich

Mark Hughes said he was "not bitter" at his press briefing on Friday but, some 11 months on, he will still keenly recall waving goodbye to Manchester City's supporters after a 4-3 victory over Sunderland that was played with Roberto Mancini sitting in the stands. There was such indignity to his sacking at Eastlands that this meeting with his former employers will offer particular incentive to excel. The visitors are fourth and apparently content with their season to date. Whether their owners will feel quite so charitable to Mancini should they lose at Craven Cottage remains to be seen. Dominic Fifield

Darren Bent's return to the squad is a welcome boost for the Sunderland manager, Steve Bruce, though the striker is not an automatic selection for the hosts following the recent goalscoring exploits of Asamoah Gyan and the form of Danny Welbeck. Considering Sunderland's last game ended in a 3-0 win at Chelsea, Bruce is unlikely to make many unnecessary changes. How Everton's manager, David Moyes, would relish such a conundrum – his strikers have scored two league goals between them this season John Stanton

After one victory in eight league games Villa's season is already looking wan but if they subject Arsenal to the kind of barrage which stunned Manchester United a fortnight ago they could win. John Carew is available after a four-match absence and Robert Pires could reacquaint himself with his former team. Arsenal are suffering the sort of injury problems which have been plaguing their opponents, with Cesc Fábregas missing again and Emmanuel Eboué likely to be out for two months. A third defeat in eight days would give Arsène Wenger another worry line. David Lacey

This fixture – the first between these sides in the top-flight for 46 years – is synonymous with the 1953 FA Cup final, one of English football's greatest matches. It might not be Lofthouse versus Matthews this weekend but their modern-day successors have served up some scintillating fare in the opening months of the season, and given both teams' attacking intentions a repeat of the 4-3 Wembley scoreline cannot be discounted. Blackpool's 14 games have featured a Premier League-high 48 goals while Owen Coyle's fifth-placed Bolton, who have outscored all but the top three, are only a couple behind. Richard Gibson

It says something for both teams' inconsistencies that they should have followed up their performances of the season with some mediocre results. West Brom have not managed an away win since overcoming Arsenal at the Emirates two months ago while Everton have tasted one victory after winning the Merseyside derby on 17 October. Having lost four of their last five games the Albion manager, Roberto Di Matteo, will want Chris Brunt to have recovered from the groin injury that kept him out last weekend, although James Morrison and Steven Reid should be fit. Tim Rich

Having washed his hands of one set of interventionist owners Mark Hughes insists the Fulham owner Mohamed Al Fayed had every right to dress down his players after their 4-1 defeat by, funnily enough, Manchester City. Hughes's side have slid down the table and are without three first-choice strikers, with Andy Johnson the latest to break down. Birmingham frequently disappoint on their travels but after taking four points off Chelsea and Manchester City they will be hopeful of recording their first away win of the season. James Callow

It may be all sweetness and light again between Wayne Rooney and the Old Trafford faithful, or at least the United striker hopes it is, but he still has to shift the significant rust from his improved frame before the reservations are dispelled. One penalty kick aside, Rooney was well below-par against Rangers in midweek and despite the chance to usurp Chelsea at the summit, Sir Alex Ferguson is expected to start the striker against Blackburn. "Playing is the name of the game for him now," he said. Darren Fletcher and possibly Paul Scholes may miss out through injury while five Rovers players require late fitness tests. Andy Hunter

Nobody likes playing Stoke, and if City win at the Britannia they may have to be taken seriously as title contenders. Both teams are in form, Stoke having won their last three and City impressing with a 4-1 victory at Fulham. Roberto Mancini will be loth to change a winning team, but Pablo Zabaleta is suspended and Mario Balotelli available again after serving a ban. Gareth Barry and Jérôme Boateng are both expected to overcome ankle trouble. Stoke have doubts about Andy Wilkinson (knee) and Jermaine Pennant (hamstring), but Jon Walters, who scored twice at West Brom last week, has recovered from the groin injury he sustained at The Hawthorns. Joe Lovejoy

Avram Grant insists this game will not make or break West Ham's season but a defeat could leave them further adrift and would surely damage confidence even more. Given the listless display from West Ham at Anfield last week, the very least the manager's employers will demand to see is more convincing signs that the players want Grant to keep his job. West Ham's leaky defence will hardly get a better chance to keep a rare clean sheet, since Wigan, already the lowest scorers in the league, will be without the suspended striker Hugo Rodallega. Paul Doyle

Mick McCarthy maintains that his Wolves side are not far short of ensnaring their much-needed prey – three points – but four successive defeats, after a stirring 2-1 victory over Manchester City, suggest that they could go hungry a while longer. Sunderland, McCarthy's former club, could provide easy pickings at the back, with Michael Turner and Titus Bramble, their central defenders, ruled out until the New Year. Still, Sunderland are unbeaten in four games, including the seismic 3-0 thumping of Chelsea at Stamford Bridge two weeks ago. Russell Kempson

With 15 goals at St James' Park, Newcastle have one of the best home scoring records in the Premier League, but they have won just two of the seven games played there. Chris Hughton also has defenders Fabricio Coloccini and Mike Williamson suspended and if his side play in an open manner again Chelsea will be confident of avoiding a third consecutive away defeat in the Premier League. Despite the Champions League victory over the Slovakia champions Zilina in midweek there is still an unease about the visitors at present. Kevin McCarra

Harry Redknapp fears that Liverpool have turned a corner in the last month or so and that they remain serious rivals to his Tottenham team for a top-four finish.
